div.head: The SCENE Changes to St. James's Park. Enter Y. Worthy and Loveless as from the Tavern— Snap following.

sp.speaker: Y. Wor.
sp.p: What a Sweet Evening tis—Prithe Ned, lets walk a little—Look how lovingly the Trees are joyned, since thou wert here, as if Nature had design'd this Walk for the private Shelter of forbddien Love.
Look here are some for making use of the Conveniency.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: But, hark ye Friend, are the Women as tame and civil as they were before I left the Town? Can they Endure the Smell of Tobacco, or Vouchsafe a Man a Word with a Dirty Cravat on?

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: Ay, that they will; for Keeping is almost out of Fashion: so that now an Honest Fellow with a Promising Back need not fear a Nights lodging for Bare Goodfellowship.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: If Whoring be so poorly encourag'd, methinks the Women shou'd turn honest in their own Defence.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: Faith I don't find there's a Whore the less for it; the Pleasure of Fornication is still the same; all the Difference is, Lewdness is not so Barefac'd, as heretofore, —Virtue is as much debased as our Money; for Maldenheads are as scarce as our Mill'd Half-crowns; and Faith, Dei gratia is as hard to be found in a Girl of Sixteen, as round the Brims of an Old Shilling.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Well, I find, in spight of Law and Duty, the fish will get the Better of the Spirit. But I see no Game yet.— Prithee Will, let's go and take t'other! Bumper to Enliven Assurance that we may come downright to the Business.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: No, no; what we have in our Bellies already, by the help of a little Fresh Air, will soon be in our Pericraniums, and work us to a right pitch, to taste the Pleasures of the Night.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: The Day thou mean'st; my Day always breaks at Sun-set. We wise Fellows, that know the Use of Life, know too that the Moon lights Men to more Pleasures than the Sun,—the Sun was meant for dull Soul of Business, and poor Rogues that have a mind to save Candles.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: Nay, the Night was always a Friend to Pleasure, and that made Diana run a Whoring by the light of her own Horns.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Right: And, prithee what made Daphne run away from Apollo, but that he wore so much Day-light about his Ears?

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: Ha! Look out Ned, there's the Enemy before you!

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Why then, as Caesar said, come follow me.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: I hope 'tis his Wife, whom I desir'd to meet me here, that she might take a View of her Soldier before she new-mounted him.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Flareit and her Maid.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: I wonder, Madam, Sir Novelty don't come yet: I am so afraid he shou'd see Narcissa, and find out the trick of your Letter.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: No! No! Narcissa is out of the way: I am sure he won't be long; for, I heard the Hautbois, as they pass'd by me, mention his Name; I suppose to make the Intrigue more Fashionable, he intends to give me the Musick.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Suppose he do take you for Narcissa, What Advantage do you propose by it?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: I shall then have a just occasion to Quarrel with him for his Perfidiousness, and so force his Pocket to make his Peace with me: Beside, my Jealousie will not let me rest till I am reveng'd.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Jealousie! why, I have often heard you say, you loath'd him!

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: 'Tis my Pride, not Love, that makes me Jealous: For, though I don't love him, yet I am incens'd to think he Dares love another.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: See! Madam, Here he is, and the Musick with him.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Put on your Mask, and leave me.—

div.stage: Enter Sir Novelty with the Musick.

sp.speaker: Sir Nov.
sp.p: Here, Gentlemen, place your selves on this Spot, and pray oblige me with a Trumpet Sonata [The Musick prepare to Play].—This taking a Man at his first word, is a very new way of preserving Reputation, stop my Vitals,—nay, and secure one too; for now may we Enjoy and grow Weary of one another, before the Town can take any notice of us. [Flareit making towards him] Ha! this must be She.—I suppose, Madam, you are no Stranger to the Contents of this Letter.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Dear Sir, this place is too publick for my Acknowledgment, if you please to withdraw to a more Private Conveniency.

div.stage: The Musick prepare to Play, and all sorts of People gather about it. Enter at one Door Nar. Hill. Am. Eld. Worthy, and Y. Worthy; at another Loveless and Snap, who talk to the Masks.

sp.speaker: E. W.
sp.p: What say you Ladies, shall we walk Homewards? It begins to be dark.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: Prithee don't be so Impatient, it's light enough to hear the Musick, I'll warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Mr. Worthy, you promis'd me a Sight I long for: Is Mr. Loveless Among all those?

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: That's He, Madam, a surveying that Masked Lady.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Ha! Is't possible! Methinks I read his Vices in his Person! Can he be Insensible, ev'n to the smart of Pinching Poverty? Pray, Sir, your Hand,—I find my self Disorder'd. It troubles me to think I dare not speach to him after so long an Absence.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: Madam, your staying here may be Dangerous, therefore let me Advise you to go home, and get all things in order to Receive him: About an hour hence will be a convenient time to set my Design a-going; till when let me beg you to have a little Patience: Give me Leave, Madam, to see you to your Coach.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: I'll not trouble you, Sir, yonder's my Cousin Welbred, I'll beg his Protection.

div.stage: The Musick Plays, after which Nar. speaks.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.p: I vow it's very fine, considering what dull Souls our Nation are: I find 'tis an harder matter to reform their Manners than their Government, or Religion.

sp.speaker: E. W.
sp.p: Since the One has been so happily Accomplish'd, I know no reason why we should despair of the Other: I hope in a little time to see our Youth return from Travel Big with Praises of their own Country. But come, Ladies, the Musicks's done I suppose, shall we walk?

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.p: Time enough, why you have no Tast of the true Pleasure of the Park: I'll warrant you hate as much to ridicule others, as to hear your self prais'd: for my part, I think a little harmless Railing's half the Pleasure of ones Life.

sp.speaker: E. W.
sp.p: I don't love to create my self Enemies by observing the Weakness of other People; I have more Faults of my own than I know how to mend.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.p: Protect me! How can you see such a Medley of Human Stuffs as here is, without venting your Spleen? —Why look there now, is not it Comical to see that wretched Creature there with her Autumnal Face, dresft in all the Colours of the Spring?

sp.speaker: E. W.
sp.p: Pray, who is she Madam?

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.p: A thing that won't believe her self out of date, though she was a Known Woman at the Restauration.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: O! I know her, 'tis Mrs. Holdout, one that is proud of being an Original of Fashionable Fornication, and values her self mightily for being one of the first Mistrisses that ever kept her Coach publickly in England.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: Pray who's that Impudent young Fellow there?

sp.speaker: E. W.
sp.p: Oh, that's an Eternal Fan-tearer, and a constant Persecuter of Woman-kind: He had a great Misfortune lately.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.p: Pray what was it?

sp.speaker: E. W.
sp.p: Why, impudently presuming to Cuckold a Dutch Officer, he had his fore-teeth kick'd out.

sp.speaker: Omnes,
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.p: There's another too, Mr. Worthy, do you know him?

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: That's Beau Noisy, one that brags of Favours from my Lady, tho' refused by her Woman; that Sups with my Lord, and borrows his Club of his Footman; that beats the Watch, and is kick'd by his Companions; that is one day at Court, and the next in Jayl; that goes to Church without Religion, is valiant without Courage, witty without Sense, and Drunk without Measure.

sp.speaker: E. W.
sp.p: A very Compleat Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: Prithee Cousin, who's that over-shy Lady there, that won't seem to understand what that Brisk young fellow says to her?

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.p: Why, that's my Lady Slylove: That other Ceremonious Gentleman is her Lover: She is so overmodest, that she makes a scruple of Shifting her self before her Woman, but afterwards makes none of doing it before her Gallant.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: Hang her, she's a Jest to the whole Town: For, tho' she has been the Mother of two By blows, endeavours to appear as Ignorant in all Company as if she did not know the Distinction of Sexes.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.p: Look, Look! Mr. Worthy, I vow there's the Countess of Incog out of her Disabillee, in a high Head, I protest!

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: 'Tis as great a wonder to see her out of an Hackney Coach, as out of Debtor—.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.p: Or out of Countenance.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: That, indeed, she seldom changes; for she is never out of a Mask, and is so well known in't, that when she has a mind to be Private, she goes Barefac'd.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.p: But come, Cousin, now let's see what Monsters the next Walk affords.

sp.speaker: E. Wor.
sp.p: With all my Heart, 'tis in our way home.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: Ladies, I must beg your Pardon for a moment, yonder comes one I have a little business with, I'll dispatch it immediately, and follow you.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: No, no; we'll stay for you.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.p: You may, if you please, Cousin; but, I suppose, he will hardly thank you for't.

sp.speaker: Hill
sp.p: What, then you conclude 'tis a Womans business, by his promising a quick dispatch!

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: Madam, in three minutes you shall know the Business, if it displease you, condemn me to an Eternal absence.

sp.speaker: E. W.
sp.p: Come, Madam, let me be his Security.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.p: I dare take your Word, Sir—

div.stage: Exeunt E. Wo. Hill. and Nat:
Enter Sly, Servant to Young Worthy.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: Well! how go matters, is she in a Readiness to receive him?

sp.speaker: Sly,
sp.p: To an Hair, Sir, every Servant has his Cue, and all are Impatient till the Comedy begins.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: Stand aside a little, and let us watch our Opportunity.

sp.speaker: Snap,
sp.p: [To a Mask] Enquire about half an hour hence for Number Two, at the Gridiron.

sp.speaker: Mask,
sp.p: To morrow with all my Heart, but to Night I am engaged to the Chaplain of Collonel Thunder's Regiment.

sp.speaker: Snap,
sp.p: What, will you leave me for a Mutton-chop, for that's all he'l give you, I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Mask,
sp.p: You are mistaken, faith he keeps me.

sp.speaker: Snap,
sp.p: Not to himself, I'll engage him: Yet he may too, if no body likes you no better than I do. Hark you Child, prithee when was your Smock wash'd?

sp.speaker: Mask,
sp.p: Why dost thou pretend to fresh Linnen, that never wore a clean Shirt but of thy Mothers own Washing?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: What, no Adventure, no Game, Snap?

sp.speaker: Snap,
sp.p: None, None, Sir, I can't prevail with any from the point Headoloths to the Horse-Guard-Whore.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: What a-Pox! sure the Whores can't smell an Empty Pocket.

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.p: No, no, that's Certain, Sir, they must see it in our Faces▪

sp.speaker: Sly,
sp.p: [to Loveless] My Dear Boy, how is't? I-gad, I am glad thou art come to Town: My Lady expected you above an hour ago, and I am overjoy'd I ha' found thee: Come, come, come along, she's Impatient till she sees you.

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.p: Odsbud, Sir, follow him, he takes you for another.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I-gad, it looks with the face of an Intrigue—, I'll humour him—: Well, what, shall we go now?

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Ay, ay, now it's pure and dark, you may go undiscover'd.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: That's what I would do.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Odsheart, she longs to see thee, and she is a curious fine Creature, ye Rogue! such Eyes! such Lips!— and such a Tongue between 'em! ah, the Tip of it will set a Mans Soul on fire!

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: [aside] The Rogues make me Impatient!

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Come, come, the Key, the Key, the Key, you dear Rogue!

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.p: O Lord, the Key, the Key!

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: The Key: why sh—sh—sh—shu'd yo— yo—you have it?

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Ay, ay! Quickly, give's it!

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Why—what the Devil—, sure I han't lost it—; oh! no Gad, it is not there—;What the Devil shall we do?

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Oon's, ne'r stand fumbling; if you have lost it we must shoot the Lock I think.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I-gad, and so we must, for I han't it.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Come, come along, follow me.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Snap, Stand by me, you Dog.

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Sir.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: Ha, ha! the Rogue managed him most dexterously; how greedily he Chopt at the Bait? What the Event will be, Heaven knows; but thus far 'tis Pleasant; And since he is safe, I'll venture to divert my Company with the Story. Poor Amanda, thou well deservest a better Husband: Thou wert never wanting in thy Endeavours to reclaim him: And, faith, considering how a long Dispair has worn thee,
sp.l: 'Twere pity now thy Hopes should not succeed;
This new Attempt is Loves last Shift indeed.

div.head: ACT IV.
The SCENE continues.
div.stage: Enter two Bullies, and Sir William Wisewou'd observing them.

sp.speaker: 1st Bully.
sp.p: DAmme! Iack, let's after him, and fight him; 'tis not to be put up.

sp.speaker: 2d Bull.
sp.p: No! Dam him! no body saw the affront, and what need we take notice of it?

sp.speaker: 1st. Bul.
sp.p: Why that's true!—But Damme! I have much ado to forbear cutting his Throat.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Pray Gentlemen, what's the matter? Why are you in such a Passion?

sp.speaker: 1st. B.
sp.p: What's that to you, Sir? What wou'd you have?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: I hope, Sir, a Man may ask a Civil Question.

sp.speaker: 1st. B.
sp.p: Damme! Sir, we are Men of Honour; we dare answer any Man.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: But why are you angry, Gentlemen? Have you received any wrong?

sp.speaker: 2d. B.
sp.p: We have been called Rascals, Sir, have had the Lye given us, and had like to have been kickt!

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: But I hope, you were not kickt, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 2d. B.
sp.p: How, Sir! we kickt!

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Nor do I presume, that you are Rascals!

sp.speaker: 1st. B.
sp.p: Bloud! and Thunder! Sir, let any Man say it that wears an head! we Rascals!

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Very good! since then you are not Rascals, he rather was one, who maliciously call'd you so:—Pray take my Advice, Gentlemen; never disturb your selves, for any ill your Enemy says of you; for from an Enemy the World will not believe it: Now you must know, Gentlemen, that a Flea-bite is to me more offensive, than the severest Affront any Man can offer me!

sp.speaker: 1st. B.
sp.p:
What, and so you wou'd have us put it up!
Damme! Sir, don't preach Cowardice to us, we are Men of Valour: you won't find us Cowards, Sir.

sp.speaker: 2d. B.
sp.p: No, Sir! we are no Cowards, tho' you are.

sp.speaker: 1st. B.
sp.p:
Hang him▪ let him alone, I see a Coward in his
•• ce.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: If my face make any Reflection, Sir, 'tis against my will.

sp.speaker: 2d B.
sp.p: Prithee Tom, let's Affront him, and raise his Spleen a little.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Raise my Spleen! that's more than any Man cou'd ever boast of.

sp.speaker: 1st. B.
sp.p: You Lye.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: I am not angry yet, therefore I do not Lye, Sir: Now one of us must lye, I do not lye, Ergo—

sp.speaker: 1st B.
sp.p: Damme! Sir, have a care! Don't give me the Lye, I shan't take it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: I need not, Sir! you give it your self.

sp.speaker: 1st. B.
sp.p: Well, Sir, what then? if I make bold with my self, every old Puppy shall not pretend to do it.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: 1st. B.
sp.p: Damme, Sir, what do you laugh at!

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: To let you see, that I am no Puppy, Sir, for Puppies are Brutes, now Brutes have not Risibility: But I laugh, therefore I am no Puppy, ha! ha!

sp.speaker: 1st. B.
sp.p: Bloud and Thunder, Sir! dare you fight?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Not in cool blood, Sir, and I confess 'tis impossible to make me angry.

sp.speaker: 2d. B.
sp.p: I'le try that! Heark ye, don't you know you are a sniveling old Cuckold?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: No, really, Sir.

sp.speaker: 2d. B.
sp.p: Why then I know you to be one.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Look you, Sir, my Reason weighs this Injury▪ which is so light, it will not raise my Anger in the other Scale.

sp.speaker: 1st. B.
sp.p: Oon's! what a tame old Prig's this? I'll give you better weight then. I know who got all your Children.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Not so well as my Wife I presume—Now she tells me, 'twas my self, and I believe her too.

sp.speaker: 1st. B.
sp.p:
She tells you so, because the poor Rogue tha •
got 'em is not able to keep 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Then my keeping them in Charity.

sp.speaker: 1st. B.
sp.p: Bloud and Thunder, Sir, this is an Affront to us, not to be Angry after all these Provocations—Damme! Iack, let's souse him in the Canal.

div.stage: Enter El. Worthy, Young Worthy, Nar, and Hill.

sp.speaker: Y. Wor.
sp.p: S'Death, what's here? Sir William in the Rogues hands that affronted the Ladies—Oh, forbear, forbear—

sp.speaker: E. Wor.
sp.p: So, Gentlemen, I thought you had fair warning before, now you shall pay for't. (Enter three or four Sentinels.) Heark you, honest Soldiers, pray do me the favour to wash these Rascals in the Canal, and there's a Guinea for your trouble.

sp.speaker: Bullies.
sp.p: Damme, Sir! we shall expect satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Oh dear Gentlemen, I am obliged to you, for I was just going to the Canal my self, if you had not come as you did.

sp.speaker: E. Wor.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, what had you done to 'em?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Why, hearing the Musick from my Parlour Window, and being invited by the sweetness of the Evening, I ev'n took a Walk to see if I could meet with you, when the first Objects that presented themselves were these Bullies, threatning to cut some bodies Throat: Now, I endeavouring to allay their Fury, occasioned their giving me scurrilous Language: and finding they cou'd not make me as angry as themselves, they off'red to fling me into the Water.

sp.speaker: E. Wor.
sp.p: I am glad we stept to your deliverance.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Oh, I thank you, Gentlemen.—I'll e'en go home, and recover my fright. Good Night, Good Night to you all.

sp.speaker: E. W.
sp.p:
Harry, see Sir William safe to his Lodging. [To his Servant.
Well, Ladies, I believe it's time for us to be walking too.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: No, pray let me engage you to stay a little longer: Yonder comes Sir Novelty and his Mistress, in pursuance of the Design I told you of; pray have a little patience, and you will see the effect on't.

sp.speaker: E. W.
sp.p: With all my heart, Madam.

sp.speaker: Sir Nov.
sp.p: Generous Creature! this is an unexampled condescension to meet my Passion with such early kindness: Thus let me pay my soft Acknowledgments.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: You must know he has mistaken her for another.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: For Heaven's sake let me go, if Hillaria shou'd be at home before me, I am ruined for ever.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.p: Hillaria! what does she mean?

sp.speaker: Sir Nov.
sp.p: Narcissa's Reputation shall be ever safe, while my Life and Fortune can protect it.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.p: O Gad▪ let me go, does the impudent Creature take my Name upon her—I'll pull off her Head-cloaths.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: Oh! fye! Cousin, what an ungenteel Revenge wou'd that be! have a little patience.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.p: Oh! I am in a flame.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: But will you never see that common Creature Flareit more?

sp.speaker: Sir Nov.
sp.p: Never! never! Feed on such homely Fare after so rich a Banquet?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Nay, but you must hate her too.

sp.speaker: Sir Nov.
sp.p: That I did long ago for her stinking breath! 'Tis true, I have been led away; but I detest a Strumpet: I am informed she keeps a Fellow under my Nose, and for that reason, I wou'd not make the Settlement I lately gave her some hopes of: But e'en let her please her self, for now I am wholly yours.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Oh, now you charm me! but will you love me ever?

sp.speaker: Sir Nov.
sp.p: Will you be ever kind?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Be sure you never see Flareit more.

sp.speaker: Sir Nov.
sp.p: When I do, may this soft Hand Revenge my Perjury.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: So it shall, Villain!

div.stage: [Strikes him a box on the ear, and unmasks.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Nov.
sp.p: Flareit, the Devil!

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: What, will nothing but a Maidenhead go down with you! Thou miserable conceited Wretch—Foh! my breath stinks does it! I'm a homely Puss! a Strumpet, not worth you notice! Devil, I'll be reveng'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Nov.
sp.p: Damn your Revenge, I'm sure I feel it.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.p: Really, Sir Novelty, I am obliged to you, for your kind thoughts of me, and your extraordinary care of my Reputation.

sp.speaker: Sir Nov.
sp.p: S'Death, she here! expos'd to half the Town!— well, I must brasen it out however!

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: What! no Pretence! no Evasion now!

sp.speaker: Sir Nov.
sp.p: There's no occasion for any, Madam.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Come come, swear you knew me all this while.

sp.speaker: Sir Nov.
sp.p: No, faith, Madam, I did not know you: For if I had, you wou'd not have found me so furious a Lover.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Furies and Hell! dares the Monster own his guilt! this is beyond all sufferance! thou Wretch, thou Thing, thou Animal, that I (to the everlasting forfeiture of my Sense and Understanding) have made a Man. For till thou knewest me, 'twas doubted if thou wert of Humane kind. And dost thou think I'll suffer such a worm as Thee to turn against me! No! when I do, may I be curs'd to thy Embraces all my Life, and never know a Joy beyond thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Nov.
sp.p: Why—wh—wh—what will your Ladyship's Fury do, Madam?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Only change my Lodging, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Nov.
sp.p: I shall keep mine, Madam, that you may know where to find me when your fury is over—You see I am good natur'd.

div.stage:
[VValks by her.
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: This Bravery's affected: I know he loves me, and I'll pierce him to the quick: I have yet a surer way to fool him.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: Methinks the Knight bears it bravely.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.p: I protest the Lady weeps.

sp.speaker: Y. VVor.
sp.p: She knows what she does, I'll warrant you.

sp.speaker: E. VVor.
sp.p: Ay, Ay, the Fox is a better Politician than the Lion.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: (VVith tears in her eyes) Now woman. (Aside.) Sir Novelty, pray Sir, let me speak with you.

sp.speaker: Sir Nov.
sp.p: Ay, Madam.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Before we part (for I find I have irrecoverably lost your Love) let me beg of you, that from this hour, you ne'er will see me more, or make any new attempts to deceive my easie Temper: For I find my Nature's such, I shall believe you, though to my utter Ruine.

sp.speaker: Sir Nov.
sp.p: Pray Heaven she be in earnest.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: One thing more, Sir; since our first Acquaintance, you have received several Letters from me; I hope you will be so much a Gentleman as to let me have 'em again: Those I have of yours shall be returned to Morrow Morning. And now, Sir, wishing you as much Happiness in her you Love, as you once pretended I cou'd give you— I take of you my everlasting leave—Farewel, and may your next Mistress love you till I hate you.

sp.speaker: Sir Nov.
sp.p: So! now must I seem to perswade her. Nay, prithee my Dear! why do you struggle so? whither wou'd you go?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, give me leave to pass, I can't bear to stay.

sp.speaker: Sir Nov.
sp.p: VVhat is't that frightens you?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Your Barbarous Usage: Pray let me go.

sp.speaker: Sir Nov.
sp.p: Nay, if you are resolved, Madam, I won't press you against your will: Your humble servant. (Leaves her) and a happy riddance, stop my Vitals.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p:
Ha! not move to call me back! so unconcerned! Oh! I cou'd tear my flesh, stab every feature in this dull,
decaying Face, that wants a Charm to hold him! Dam him! I loath him too! But shall my Pride now fall from such an height, and bear the Torture unreveng'd? No! my very Soul's on fire, and nothing but the Villain's blood shall quench it. Devil, have at thee.

div.stage: [Snatches Young Worthy's Sword, and runs at him.

sp.speaker: Y. VVor.
sp.p: Have a care, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Nov.
sp.p: Let her alone, Gentlemen, I'll warrant you.

div.stage: [Young Worthy takes the Sword from her, and holds her.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Prevented! Oh! I shall choak with boyling Gall. Oh! Oh! uumh! let me go; I'll have his blood, his blood, his blood!

sp.speaker: Sir Nov.
sp.p: Let her come, let her come, Gentlemen!

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Death and Vengeance, am I become his sport! he's pleased, and smiles to see me Rage the more! But he shall find no Fiend in Hell can match the fury of a disappointed Woman!—Scorned! slighted! dismissed without a parting Pang! Oh torturing thought! May all the Racks Mankind e'er gave our easie Sex, Neglected Love, Decaying Beauty, and hot Raging Lust light on me, if e're I cease to be the Eternal Plague of his remaining Life, nay, after Death:
sp.l: —VVhen his, his black Soul lies howling in despair,
I'd plunge to Hell, and be his Torment there.

sp.speaker: Eld. VVor▪
sp.p: Sure Sir Novelty, you never loved this Lady, if you are so indifferent at parting.

sp.speaker: Sir No.
sp.p: Why Faith Tom, to tell you the Truth, her Jealousie has been so very troublesome and expensive to me of late, that I have these Three Months sought an opportunity to leave her; but Faith I had always more respect to my Life, than to let her know it before.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: Methinks, Sir Novelty, you had very little respect to her Life, when you drew upon her.

sp.speaker: Sir No.
sp.p:
Why what wou'd you have had me done, Madam? Complemented her with my naked Bosom! No! No! look ye, Madam, if she had made any Advances▪
I cou'd have disarm'd her in Second at the very first Pass —But come, Ladies, as we walk, I'll beg your Judgments in a particular nice Fancy, that I intend to appear in, the very first Week the Court is quite out of Mourning.

sp.speaker: Eld. Wor.
sp.p: With all my heart, Sir Novelty.—Come Ladies, considering how little rest you'll have to morrow night, I think 'twere Charity not to keep you up any longer.

sp.speaker: Y. VVor.
sp.p: Nay as for that matter, the night before a Wedding is as unfit to sleep in, as the Night following: Imagination's a very troublesome Bedfellow:—Your Pardon, Ladies, I only speak for my self.

sp.speaker: Eld. VVor.
sp.p: See the Coaches ready at St. Iames's Gate

div.stage: Enter Two Servants. The SCENE Amanda's House.

sp.speaker: 1st. Ser.
sp.p: Come, come, make hast; is the Supper, and the Musick ready?

sp.speaker: 2d. Ser.
sp.p: It is, It is: Well! is he come?

sp.speaker: 1st. Ser.
sp.p: Ay, Ay, I came before to tell my Lady the News; That Rogue Sly manag'd him rarely, he has been this half hour pretending to pick the Lock of the Garden-door: Well poor Lady! I wish her good Luck with him: For she's certainly the best Mistress living. Heark ye, is the Wine strong, as she order'd it? Be sure you ply him home: for he must have two or three Bumpers to qualifie him for her Design. See here he comes: Away to your Post.

div.stage: Enter Loveless, conducted by Sly, Snap stealing after them.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Where the Devil will this Fellow lead me— Nothing but Silence, and Darkness!—sure the House is haunted, and he has brought me to face the Spirit at his wonted hour!

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: There, there, in, in,—Slip on your Night-Gown, and refresh your self; in the mean time I'll acquaint my Lady, that you are here.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Snap.

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.p: Ay, Ay, Sir, I'll warrant you.

div.head: The Scene changes to an Anti-Chamber, a Table, Light, a Night Gown, and a Perriwig lying by. They Re-enter

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Ha! what sweet Lodgings are here? where can this end?

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.p: I gad, Sir, I long to know—Pray Heaven we are not deluded hither to be stan'd—Methinks I wish I had brought the Remnants of my Dinner with me.

sp.speaker: Lov.
Snap.
sp.p: Well Sir, I'll line this Trench in case of your being in danger.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Ha! This Night-Gown and Peruke don't lye here for nothing.—I'll make my self agreeable.—I have baulk't many a Woman in my time, for want of a lean Shirt.—

div.stage: Enter Servants with a Supper, after them, a Man; Woman.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Ha! a Supper! Heaven send it be no Vision! If the Meat be real, I shall believe the Lady may prove Flesh and Bloud.—Now am I damnably puzled to know whether this be she, or no • Madam—

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Sir, my Lady begs your pardon for a moment.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Humh! her Lady! Good.—

sp.speaker: Wom.
Lov.
sp.p: Not alone; Madam, you must bear me Company.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: To oblige you, Sir, I'll exceed my Commission.

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.p: (Vnder the Table.) Was there ever so unfortunate a Dog! What the Devil put it in my head to hide my self before Supper; why this is worse than being lock'd into a Closet, while another Man's a Bed with my Wife! I suppose my Master will take as much care of me too, as I shou'd of him, if I were in his Place.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Sir, my humble Service to you.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Madam, your humble Servant: I'll pledge you. Snap, when there's any danger I'll call you; in the mean time lye still, d' hear.

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.p: Igad I'll shift for my self then: (snatches a Flask unseen) so, now I am arm'd, defiance to all Danger.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Madam, your Lady's Health.

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.p: Ay, Ay, let it go round, I say.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Well really Sir my Lady's very happy, that she has got loose from her Relations: for they were always teizing her about you: But she defies 'em all now.— Come Sir, Success to both your Wishes.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Give me a Glass; methinks this Health inspires me—My Heart grows lighter for the Weight of Wine; —Here, Madam,—Prosperity to the Man, that ventures most to please her.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: What think you of a Song to support this Gaity?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: With all my Heart.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: You have oblig'd me, Madam; Igad I like this Girl! she takes off her Glass so feelingly, I am half perswaded she's of a thirsty Love: If her Lady don't make a little hast, I find I shall present my humble Service to her.

div.stage: Enter a Servant, who whispers Amanda's Woman.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Sir I ask your Pardon, my Lady has some Commands for me, I will return immediately.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Your Servant.—Methinks this is a very new Method of Intriguing!

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.p:
Pray Heaven it be N • w! for the Old way commonly
ended in a good beating! But a Pox of Danger I say, and so here's good Luck to you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Take heed, Rogue, you don't get drunk, and discover your self.

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.p: It must be with a fresh Flask then; for this is expired Supernatulum.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Lie close, you Dog; I hear somebody coming▪ I am impatient till I see this Creature. This Wine has armed me against all thoughts of danger! Pray Heaven she be young, for then she can't want Beauty. Ha! here she comes! Now! never-falling Impudence assist me.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Where's my Love? O, let me fly into his Arms, and live for ever there.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: My Life, my Soul! (runs and embraces her.) by Heaven a tempting Creature! Melting, soft, and warm,— as my desire—Oh, that I cou'd hide my face for ever thus, that undiscovered I might reap the Harvest of a Ripe desire, without the lingring pains of growing Love.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Look up, my Lord, and bless me with a tender look, and let my talking Eyes inform thee how I have languish'd for thy absence.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Let's retire, and chase away our fleeting Cares with the Raptures of untir'd Love.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Bless me! your Voice is strangely alter'd! Ha! defend me! who's this? help! help! within there?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: So! I am discover'd! A Pox on my tatling! that I cou'd not hold my Tongue till I got to her Bed-Chamber.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Did your Ladyship call help, Madam, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Villain! Slave! who's this? what Ruffian have you brought me here—Dog, I'll have you murder'd!

sp.speaker: Sly.
Am.
sp.p: Be dumb! Eternal Block head—here! Take this Fellow, toss him in a Blanket, and let him be turn'd out of my doors immediately.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: O Pray! Dear Madam, for Heavens sake, I am a ruin'd Man—

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.p: Ah! Snap, what will become of thee? Thou art fall'n into the hands of a Tygress that has lost her Whelp; I have no hopes, but in my Master's Impudence! Heaven strengthen it!

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: I'll hear no more! away with him!

div.p: Now, Sir, for you▪ I expected—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: A Man, Madam, did you not?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Not a Stranger, Sir; But one that has a Right and Title to that welcome, which by mistake has been given to you.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Not an Husband, I presume he wou'd not have been so privately conducted to your Chamber, and in the dark too!

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Whoever it was, Sir, is not your business to Examine: But if you wou'd have Civil Usage, pray be gone.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: To be used Civilly, I must stay, Madam: There can be no danger with so fair a Creature.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: I doubt you are mad, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: While my Senses, have such luscious Food before 'em, no wonder if they are in some Confusion, each striving to be foremost at the Banquet, and sure my greedy, Eyes will starve the rest.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, keep your distance, lest your feeling too be gratified.

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.p: O Lord! wou'd I were 100 Leagues off at Sea!

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Then briefly thus, Madam, know I like and love you: Now if you have so much Generosity as to let me know, what Title my pretended Rival has to your Person, or your Inclinations: Perhaps the little hopes I then may have of supplanting him, may make me leave your House. If not, my Love shall still pursue you, tho' to the hazard of my Life, which I shall not easily resigh, while this Sword can guard it, Madam.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Oh, were this Courage shown but in a better Cause, how worthy were the Man that own'd it! (Aside.) What is it, Sir, that you propose by this unnecessary Trifling? Know then, that I did expect a Lover, a Man perhaps more brave than you: One, that if present, wou'd have given you a shorter Answer to your Question.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I am glad to hear he's brave, however; it betrays no weakness in your Choice: But if you'd still preserve, or raise the Joys of Love, remove him from your thoughts a moment, and in his room receive a warmer Heart, a Heart that must admire you more than he, because my Passion's of a fresher Date.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: What de'e take me for?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: A Woman, and the most Charming of your Sex; one whose pointed Eyes declare you form'd for Love, and tho' your words are flinty; your every look and motion all confess there's a secret Fire within you, which must sparkle, when the Steel of Love provokes it. Come, now pull away your hand, and make me hold it faster.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Nay, now you are rude, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: If Love be Rudeness, let me be Impudent▪ When we are Familiar, Rudeness will be Love. No Woman ever thought a Lover Rude after she had once granted him the Favour.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Pray Sir, forbear.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: How can I? when my desire's so violent: Oh, let me snatch the Rosie Dew from those distilling Lips, and as you see your power to Charm, so chide me with your Pity. Why do you thus cruelly turn away your Face? I own the Blessing's worth an Ages Expectation, but if refused till merited, 'tis esteemed a Debt. Wou'd you oblige your Lover, let loose your early Kindness.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: I shall not take your Counsel, Sir, while I know a Woman's early Kindness is as little sign of her Generosity, as her Generosity is a sign of her Discretion: Nor wou'd I have you believe I am so ill provided for, that I need listen to any Man's first Addresses.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Why, Madam, wou'd not you drink the first time you had a Thirst?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Yes; but not before I had.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: If you can't drink, yet you may kiss the Cup, and that may give you inclination.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Your Pardon, Sir, I drink out of no body's Glass but my own; as the Man I love confines himself to me, so my Inclination keeps me true to him.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: That's a Cheat imposed upon you, by your own Vanity; For, when your back's turn'd, your very Chamber-Maid sips of your leavings, and becomes your Rival. Constancy in Love is all a Cheat, Women of your Understanding know it: The Joys of Love are only Great when they are new, and to make 'em lasting, we must often change.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Suppose 'twere a fresh Lover I now expected.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Why then, Madam, your Expectation's answer'd; For, I must confess I don't take you for an Old Acquaintance, tho' somewhere I have seen a Face not much unlike you. Come, your Arguments are vain; for they are so Charmingly delivered, they but inspire me the more, as blows in Battel raise the brave Man's Courage. Come, every thing pleads for me, Your Beauty, Wit, Time, Place, Opportunity, and my own Excess of Raging Passion.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Stand off: distant as the Globes of Heaven and Earth, that like a falling Star I may shoot with greater force into your Arms, and think it Heaven to lye Expiring there.

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.p: Ah! ah! ah! Rogue, the day's our own.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Thou sweetest, softest Creature Heav'n e'er form'd; Thus let me twine my self about thy beauteous Limbs, till struggling with the Pangs of painful Bliss, motionless and mute we yield to Conquering Love, both Vanquish'd, and both Victors.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Can all this heat be real? Oh, why has hateful Vice such power to Charm? while poor abandon'd Vertue lies neglected.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Come, let us Surfeit on our new-born Raptures, let's waken sleeping Nature with Delight, till we may justly say, now! now! we live!

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p:
Come on, let's indulge the Transports of our present
Bliss, and bid defiance to our future change of Fate. Who waits there?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Bring me word immediately if my Apartment's ready, as I order'd it. O, I am charm'd, I have found the Man to please me now: One that can, and dares maintain the Noble Rapture of a Lawless Love: I own my self a Libertine, a Mortal Foe to that dull thing call'd Vertue, that meer Disease of sickly Nature. Pleasure's the end of Life, and while I'm Mistress of my self, and Fortune, I will enjoy it to the height. Speak freely then, (not that I love like other women the nauseous Pleasure of a little Flattery) but answer me like a Man that scorns a Lye: Does my Face invite you, Sir? May I from what you see of me, propose a Pleasure to my self in pleasing you?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: By Heaven you may; I have seen all Beauties that the Sun shines on, but never saw the Sun out-shin'd before: I have measur'd half the world in search of Pleasure: But not returning home, had ne'er been happy.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Spoken like the Man I wish might love me—Pray Heaven his words prove true. (Aside.)—Be sure you never flatter me, and when my Person tires you, confess it freely: For change when e'er you will, I'll change as soon: But while we chance to meet still let it be with Raging Fire: No matter how soon it dies, provided the small time it lasts, it burn the fiercer.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: O! wou'd the blinded world, like us, agree to change, how lasting might the Joys of Love be? For thus Beauty, tho' stale to one, might somewhere else be new; and while this Man were blest in leaving what he loath'd, another were new-Ravish'd in receiving what he ne'er enjoy'd.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Madam, every thing is according to your Order.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Oh! lead me to the Scene of unsupportable Delight, Rack me with Pleasures never known before, till I lye gasping with Convulsive Passion: This Night let us be lavish to our unbounded wishes.
sp.l: Give all our Stock at once to raise the Fire,
And Revel to the height of loose Desire.

sp.speaker: Am. Wom.
sp.p: Ah! what an happy Creature's my Lady now! There's many an unsatisfied Wife about Town, wou'd be glad to have her Husband as wicked as my Master, upon the same Terms my Lady has him▪ Few Women I'm afraid wou'd grudge an Husband the laying out his stock of Love, that cou'd receive such considerable Interest for it! Well—Now shan't I take one wink of sleep for thinking how they'll employ their time to Night—Faith, I must listen if I were to be hang'd for't.

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.p: So! my Master's provided for, therefore 'tis time for me to take care of my self: I have no mind to be lock'd out of my Lodging: I fancy there • s room for two in the Maid's bed, as well as my Lady's—This same Flask was plaguy strong Wine—I find I shall storm, if she don't surrender fairly. By your leave, Damsel.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Bless me! who's this? O Lord! what wou'd you have? who are you?

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.p: One that has a Right and Title to your body, my Master having already taken Possession of your Lady's.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Let me go, or I'll cry out.

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.p: Ye Lye, ye dare not disturb your Lady: but the better to secure you, Thus I stop your mouth.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Humh!—Lord bless me, is the Devil in you, tearing ones things!

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.p: Then show me your Bed-Chamber.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: The Devil shall have you first.

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.p: A shall have us both together then: Here will I fix, (takes her about the Neck) just in this posture till to Morrow Morning: In the mean time when you find your Inclination stirring, prithee give me a call, for at present I am very sleepy.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Foh! how he stinks. (He belches.) Ah! what a whiff was there—the Rogue's as drunk as a Saylor with a Twelve Months Arrears in his Pocket; or a Iacobite upon a day of ill News. I'll ha nothing to say to him—let me see, how shall I get rid of him—O! I have it! I'll soon make him sober I'll warrant him: So ho! Mr. What de'e call'um, where do you intend to lye to Night?

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.p: Humh! why, where you lay last Night, unless you change you Lodging.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Well, for once I'll take Pity of you—make no noise, but put out the Candles, and follow me softly, for fear of disturbing my Lady.

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.p: I'll warrant ye! there's no fear of spoyling her Musick, while we are playing the same Tune.

div.head: The Scene changes to a dark Entry, and they Re-enter.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Where are you? lend me your hand.

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.p: Here! Here! make hast, my dear Concupiscence.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Hold! stand there a little, while I open the Door gently without waking the Footmen.

div.stage: [She feels about, and opens a Trap door.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Come along softly this way!

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.p: Where abouts are you?

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Here, here, come strait forward.

div.stage: [He goes forward, and falls into the Cellar.

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.p: O Lord! O Lord! I have broke my Neck.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: I am glad to hear him say so, however I shou'd be loath to be hang'd for him. How de'e, Sir?

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.p: De'e, Sir! I am a League under Ground.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Where abouts are you?

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.p: In Hell, I think.

sp.speaker: VVom.
sp.p: No! No! you are but in the Road to it, I dare say: Ah dear! why will you follow lewd Women at this rate, when they lead you to the very Gulph of Destruction? I knew you wou'd be swallow'd up at last. Ha! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.p: Ah, ye sneering Whore!

sp.speaker: VVom.
sp.p: Shall I fetch you a Prayer-Book, Sir? to Arm you against the Temptations of the Flesh!

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.p: No! you need but show your own damn'd ugly Face to do that—Heark ye, either help me out, or I'll Hang my self, and swear your Murder'd me.

sp.speaker: VV.
sp.p: Nay, if you are so bloody-minded, Good Night to ye, Sir.

div.stage: [She offers to shut the Door over him, and he catches hold on her.

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.p: Ah! Ah! Ah! have I caught you! Igad we'll Pig together now.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: O Lord! Pray let me go, and I'll do any thing.

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.p: And so you shall before I part with you, (Pulls her in to him.) And now, Master, my Humble Service to you.

div.head: ACT V.
The SCENE Sir William Wisewou'd's House.
div.stage: Enter Eld. Worthy, Yo. Worthy, and a Lawyer with Writing.

sp.speaker: E. Wor.
sp.p: ARE the Ladies ready?

sp.speaker: Y. Wor.
sp.p: Hillaria is just gone up to hasten her Cousin, and Sir William will be here immediately.

sp.speaker: E. Wor.
sp.p: But heark you, Brother! I have consider'd of it, and pray let me oblige you not to pursue your design upon his Five thousand Pound: For in short, 'tis no better than a Cheat, and what a Gentleman shou'd scorn to be guilty of. Is not it sufficient that I consent to your wronging him of his Daughter?

sp.speaker: Y. Wor.
sp.p: Your Pardon, Brother, I can't allow that a wrong: For his Daughter loves me, her Fortune, you know, he has nothing to do with; and it's a hard case a Young Woman shall not have the disposal of her Heart. Love's a Fever of the Mind, which nothing but our own wishes can asswage, and I don't Question but we shall find Marriage a very cooling Cordial.—And as to the Five Thousand Pound, 'tis no more than what he has endeavour'd to cheat his Niece of.

sp.speaker: E. VV.
sp.p: What de'e mean, I take him for an Honest Man!

sp.speaker: Y. VVor.
sp.p:
Oh! Very honest! As honest as an Old Agent to a New-Rais'd Regiment—No Faith, I'll say that for him, he will not do an ill thing unless he gets by it. In a word, this so very honest Sir VVilliam, as you take him to be, has offer'd me the refusal of your Mistress; and
upon Condition I will secure him Five Thousand Pound upon my day of Marriage with her, he will secure me her Person, and Ten Thousand Pound, the remaining part of her Fortune! There's a Guardian for ye! What think ye now, Sir?

sp.speaker: E. W.
sp.p: Why I think he deserves to be serv'd in the same kind! I find Age, and Avarice are inseparable! therefore ev'n make what you can of him, and I will stand by you. But heark you, Mr. Forge, are you sure it will stand good in Law if Sir William signs the Bond?

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: In any Court in England, Sir.

sp.speaker: E. W.
sp.p: Then there's your Fifty Pieces, and if it succeeds, here are as many more in the same Pocket to answer 'em: But Mum—here comes Sir William and the Ladies.

div.stage: Enter Sir William Wisewou'd, Hillaria, and Narcissa.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Good morrow Gentlemen! Mr. Worthy, give you Joy! od so! If my heels were as light as my Heart, I shou'd ha' much adoe to forbear dancing—Here, here, take her, Man, (gives him Narcissa's hand) she's yours, and so is her Thousand pound a year, and my Five Thousand pound shall be yours too.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: You must ask me leave first.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Odso! is the Lawyer come?

sp.speaker: E. W.
sp.p: He is, and all the Writings are ready, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir VVil.
sp.p: Come, Come, let's see, Man! What's this! Odd! this Law is a plaguy troublesome thing; for now adays it won't let a Man give away his own, without repeating the Particulars 500 times over: When in former times a Man might have held his Title to Twenty thousand pound a year, in the compass of an Horn-Book.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: That is, Sir, Because there are more Knaves now adays, and this Age is more Treacherous and Distrustful than heretofore.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: That is, Sir, because there are more Lawyers than heretofore: But come, what's this, prithee?

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p:
These are the Old Writings of your Daughter's Fortune; this is Mr. VVorthy's Settlement upon her,— and this, Sir, is your Bond for Five thousand pound to
him: There wants nothing but filling up the Blanks with the Party's Names; if you please, Sir, I'll do't immediately.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Do so.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: May I crave your Daughter's Christian Name, the rest I know, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Narcissa! prithee make hast—

sp.speaker: Y. VVor.
sp.p: You know your Business—

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: I'll warrant you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Mr. VVorthy, methinks your Brother does not relish your Happiness as he shou'd do: Poor Man! I'll warrant he wishes himself in his Brother's condition!

sp.speaker: Y. VVor.
sp.p: Not I, I'll assure you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Niece! Niece! have you no Pity? Prithee look upon him a little! Odd! he's a pretty young Fellow —I am sure he loves you, or he wou'd not have frequented my House so often! De'e think his Brother cou'd not tell my Daughter his own Story without his Assistance! Pshaw! waw! I tell you, you were the Beauty that made him so assiduous: Come, come, give him your Hand, and he'll soon creep into your Heart, I'll warrant you: Come, say the word, and make him happy.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: What, to make my self miserable, Sir, Marry a Man without an Estate?

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Hang an Estate! True Love's beyond all Riches! 'Tis all dirt—meer dirt!—beside han't you Fifteen Thousand Pound to your Portion?

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: I doubt, Sir, you wou'd be loath to give him your Daughter, tho' her Fortune's larger.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Odd, if he loved her but half so well, as he loves you, he shou'd have her for a word speaking.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: But, Sir, this asks some Consideration—

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.p: You see, Mr. VVorthy, what an extraordinary Kindness my Father has for you!

sp.speaker: Y. VVor.
sp.p: Ay, Madam, and for your Cousin too: But I hope with a little of your Assistance we shall be both able very shortly to return it.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.p:
Nay, I was always ready to serve Hillaria; for
Heaven knows I only Marry to Revenge her Quarrel to my Father: I cannot forgive his off'ring to sell her.

sp.speaker: Y. VVor.
sp.p: O, you need not take such pains, Madam, to conceal your Passion for me; you may own it without a blush upon your Wedding-day.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.p: My Passion! When did you hear me acknowledge any? If I thought you cou'd believe me guilty of such a Weakness, tho' after I had marry'd you, I wou'd never look you in the Face.

sp.speaker: Y. VVor.
sp.p: A very pretty Humour, this faith! (Aside.) What a world of unnecessary Sins have we two to Answer for? For she has told more Lyes to conceal her Love, than I have sworn false Oaths to promote it. Well, Madam, at present I'll content my self with your giving me leave to Love.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.p: Which if I don't give, you'll take I suppose.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: Well, Uncle, I won't Promise you, but I'll go to Church and see them marry'd; when we come back 'tis ten to one but I surprize you where you least think on.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Why, that's well said!—Mr. VVorthy, now! now's your time; Odd! I have so fir'd her, 'tis not in her power to deny you, Man—To her! to her! I warrant her thy own, Boy! You'll keep your word, Five Thousand Pound upon the day of Marriage.

sp.speaker: Y. VVor.
sp.p: I'll give you my Bond upon demand, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: O! I dare take your Word, Sir.—Come, Lawyer, have you done? Is all ready?

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: All, Sir! This is your Bond to Mr. VVorthy: Will you be pleased to Sign that first, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Ay, ay; let's see! The Condition of this Obligation (Reads.) Hum um—Come, lend me the Pen.— There—Mr. VVorthy, I deliver this as my Act and Deed to you, and Heaven send you a good Bargain—Niece, will you Witness it? (which she does)—Come, Lawyer, your Fist too.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: Now, Sir, if you please to Sign the Joynture.

sp.speaker: E. VVor.
sp.p:
Come on—Sir VVilliam, I deliver this to you for the use of your Daughter. Madam, will you give your
self the trouble once move? (Hill. sets her Hand.) Come, Sir— (the Lawyer does the same.) So, now let a Coach be called as soon as you please, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: You may save that Charge, I saw your own at the Door.

sp.speaker: E. VVor.
sp.p: Your Pardon, Sir, that wou'd make our business too Publick: For which Reason, Sir VVilliam, I hope you will excuse our not taking you along with us.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Ay, ay, with all my heart, the more Privacy the less Expence. But pray, what time may I expect you back again? For Amanda has sent to me for the Writings of her Husband's Estate: I suppose she intends to Redeem the Mortgage, and I am afraid she will keep me there till Dinner-time.

sp.speaker: Y. VVor.
sp.p: Why, about that time she has obliged me to bring some of her nearest Friends to be Witnesses of her good or evil Fortune with her Husband: Methinks I long to know her Success; if you please, Sir VVilliam, we'll meet you there.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: With all my heart— (Enter a Servant.) Well! is the Coach come?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: It is at the Door, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: Come, Gentlemen, no Ceremony; your time's short.

sp.speaker: E. VVor.
sp.p: Your Servant, Sir VVilliam.

div.stage: [Exeunt E. VVor. Y. VVor. Nar. and Hill.

sp.speaker: Sir VVill.
sp.p: So! here's Five Thousand Pounds got with a wet finger! This 'tis to read Mankind! I knew a Young Lover wou'd never think he gave too much for his Mistress! VVell! if I don't suddenly meet with some misfortune, I shall never be able to bear this Tranquillity of Mind.

div.head: The SCENE changes to Amanda's House.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p:
Thus far my hopes have all been answer'd, and my disguise of Vicious Love has charm'd him ev'n to a Madness of Impure Desire:—But now I tremble to pull off the Mask, lest bare fac'd Vertue shou'd fright him from my
Arms for ever. Yet sure there are Charms in Vertue, nay, stronger, and more pleasing far, than hateful Vice can boast of! Else why have Holy Martyrs perish'd for its sake? While Lewdness ever gives severe Repentance, and unwilling Death.—Good Heaven inspire my heart, and hang upon my Tongue the force of Truth and Eloquence, that I may lure this wandring Falcon back to Love and Vertue— He comes, and now my dreaded Task begins!

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: How fare you, Sir? De'e not already think your self confin'd? Are you not tired with my easie Love?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: O! never! never! you have so fill'd my thoughts with Pleasures past, that but to reflect on 'em is still new Rapture to my Soul, and the Bliss must last while I have Life or Memory.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: No Flattery, Sir! I lov'd you for your plain-dealing; and to preserve my good Opinion, tell me, what think you of the Grapes persuading Juice! Come, speak freely, wou'd not the next Tavern-Bush put all this out of your head?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, to be free with you, I am apt to think you are in the right on't: For tho' Love and Wine are two very fine Tunes, yet they make no Musick, if you play them both together, separately they Ravish us: Thus the Mistress ought to make room for the Bottle, the Bottle for the Mistress, and both to wait the call of Inclination.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: That's Generously spoken—I have observ'd, Sir, in all your Discourse you confess something of a Man, that has throughly known the world!—Pray give me leave to ask you, of what Condition you are, and whence you came?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Why, in the first place, Madam,—by Birth I am a Gentleman; by ill Friends, good Wine, and false Dice, almost a Beggar: But by your Servants mistaking me, the happiest Man, that ever Love and Beauty smil'd on.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: One thing more, Sir! Are you married?—Now my fears. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I was, but very Young.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: What was your Wife?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p:
A foolish loving thing, that built Castles in the
Air, and thought it impossible for a Man to forswear himself when he made Love.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Was she not Vertuous?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Uumh! Yes faith, I believe she might, I was ne'er Jealous of her.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Did you ne'er love her?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Ah! most damnably at first, for she was within two Women of my Maidenhead.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: What's become of her?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Why, after I had been from her beyond Sea, about Seven or Eight Years, like a very Loving Fool she died of the Pip, and civilly left me the world free to Range in.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Why did you leave her?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Because she grew stale, and I cou'd not Whore in quiet for her: Besides she was always exclaiming against my Extravagancies, particularly my Gaming; which she so violently oppos'd, that I fancy'd a Pleasure in it, which since I never found; for in one Month I lost between Eight and Ten Thousand Pound, which I had just before call'd in to pay my Debts. This Misfortune made my Creditors come so thick upon me, that I was forc'd to Mortgage the remaining part of my Estate to Purchase new Pleasure, which I knew I cou'd not do on this side the Water, amidst the Clamours of insatiate Duns, and the more hateful Noise of a Complaining Wife.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Don't you wish you had taken her Counsel tho'?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Not I, faith, Madam.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Because 'tis to no purpose: I am Master of more Philosophy, than to be concern'd at what I can't help— But now, Madam,—Pray give me leave to inform my self as far in your Condition.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: In a word, Sir, till you know me throughly, I must own my self a perfect Riddle to you.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Nay, nay, I know you are a Woman: But in what Circumstances! Wife, or Widdow.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: A Wife, Sir; a True, a Faithful, and a Vertuous Wife.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Humb! truly, Madam, your Story begins something like a Riddle! a Vertuous Wife say you! what, and was you never false to your Husband!

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: I never was by Heav'n! for Him, and only Him I still love above the World.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Good agen! pray, Madam, don't your Memory fail you sometimes? because I fancy you don't remember what you do over night!

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: I told you, Sir, I shou'd appear a Riddle to you: But if my Heart will give me leave, I'le now unloose your fetter'd Apprehension—But I must first amaze you more—Pray, Sir, satisfy me in one particular—'tis this—What are your undissembled thoughts of Vertue? Now, if you can, shake off your loose Unthinking Part, and summon all your force of manly Reason to resolve me.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, methinks this is a very odd Question for a Woman of your Character. I must confess you have amazed me.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: It ought not to amaze you! why shou'd you think I make a mock of Virtue? But last night you allow'd my understanding greater then is usual in our Sex: if so, can you believe I have no farther sense of Happiness than what this Empty, Dark and Barren World can yield me! No, I have yet a prospect of a sublimer Bliss, an Hope, that carries me to the bright Regions of Eternal Day.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Humh! I thought her last nights humour was too good to hold. I suppose by and by she will ask me to go to Church with her—Faith, Madam, in my mind this discourse is a little out of the way. You told me I shou'd be acquainted with your condition, and at present that's what I had rather be inform'd of.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Sir, you shall: But first, this Question must be answer'd; your thoughts of Virtue, Sir?—By all my Hopes of Bliss hereafter, your answering this pronounces half my Good, or Evil fate for ever: But on my knees I beg you do not speak till you have weigh'd it well—Answer me with • he same Truth, and sincerity, as you wou'd answer Heav'n at your latest hour.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Your words confound me, Madam; some wondrous Secret sure lies ripened in your Breast, and seems to struggle for its fatal birth! What is it I must answer you?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Give me your real thoughts of Virtue, Sir; can you belive there ever was a Woman truly Mistress of it, or is it only Notion?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Let me consider, Madam, (Aside) What can this mean? Why is she so earnest in her demands, and begs me to be serious, as if her Life depended on my Answer—I will resolve her, as I ought, as Truth, and Reason, and the strange occasion seems to press me.—Most of your Sex confound the very Name of Virtue; for they wou'd seem to live without desires, which cou'd they doe, that were not Virtue but the defect of unperforming Nature, and no praise to them: For who can boast a Victory when they have no Foe to Conquer? Now she alone gives the fairest proofs of Virtue, whose Conscience and whose force of Reason can curb her warm Desires, when Opportunity wou'd raise 'em: That such a Woman may be found I dare believe.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: May I believe that from your Soul you speak this undissembled truth?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Madam, you may. But still you rack me with amazement! why am I ask't so strange a Question?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: I'le give you ease immediately.—Since then you have allow'd a Woman may be Virtuous—How will you excuse the Man who leaves the Bosome of a Wife, so qualified, for the abandon'd pleasures of deceitfull Prostitutes! Ruines her Fortune! contemns her Counsel! loaths her Bed, and leaves her to the lingring miseries of Despair and Love: while in return of all these wrongs, she his poor forsaken Wife meditates no Revenge, but what her piercing Tears, and secret Vows to Heav'n for his Conversion yield her: yet still loves on, is constant and unshaken to the last! Can you believe, that such a Man can live without the stings of Conscience, and yet be master of his Senses! Conscience! did you ne'er feel the Checks of it! did it never, never tell you of your broken Vows?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p:
That you shou'd ask me this, confounds my Reason— And yet your words are utter'd with such a powerfull Accent,
they have awak'd my Soul, and strike my thoughts with horrour and remorse.—

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Then let me strike you nearer, deeper yet:— But arm your mind with gentle pity first, or I am lost for ever.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I am all Pity, all Faith, Expectation, and confused Amazement: Be kind, be quick, and ease my wonder.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Look on me well: Revive your dead remembrance: And oh! for pity's sake (Kneels) hate me not for loving long, faithfully forgive this innocent attempt of a despairing passion, and I shall die in quiet.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Hah! speak on!

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: I wonot be!—The word's too weighty for my faultring Tongue, and my Soul sinks beneath the fatal Burthen. Oh!

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Ha! she faints! look up fair Creature! Behold a Heart that bleeds for your distress, and fain wou'd share the weight of your oppressing sorrows! Oh! thou hast rais'd a thought within me, that shocks my Soul.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: 'Tis done! (rising) the Conflict's past, and Heav'n bids me speak undaunted. Know then, ev'n all the boasted Raptures of your last Nights Love you found in your Amanda's Arms—I am your Wife.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Hah!

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: For ever blest or miserable, as your next breath shall sentence me.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: My Wife! impossible! is she not dead! How shall I believe thee?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: How Time and my Afflictions may have alter'd me I know not: But here's an Indelible Confirmation (bares her Arm.) These speaking Characters, which in their cheerfull bloom our Early Passions mutually recorded.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Hah! 'tis here—'tis no Illusion, but my real Name; which seems to upbraid me as a witness of my Perjur'd Love— Oh I am confounded with my Guilt, and tremble to behold thee—Pray give me leave to think.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p:
I will. (kneels.) But you must look upon me. For only Eyes can hear the Language of the Eyes, and mine have
sure the Tenderest tale of Love to tell, that ever Misery, at the dawn of Rising-Hope cou'd utter.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I have wrong'd you. Oh! rise! basely wrong'd you! and can I see your Face?

sp.speaker: Am
sp.p: One kind, one pitying look cancels those wrongs for ever: and oh! forgive my fond presuming passion; for from my Soul I pardon and forgive you all: all, all but this, the greatest, your unkind Delay of Love.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Oh! seal my pardon with thy trembling Lips, while with this tender Grasp of fond reviving Love I seize my Bliss and stifle all thy wrongs for ever.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: No more; I'le wash away their memory in tears of flowing Joy.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Oh thou hast rouz'd me from my deep Lethargy of Vice! For hitherto my Soul has been enslav'd to loose Desires, to vain deluding Follies, and shadows of substantial bliss: but now I wake with joy to find my Rapture Real.—Thus let me kneel and pay my thanks to her, whose conquering Virtue has at last subdu'd me. Here will I fix, thus prostrate sigh my shame, and wash my Crimes in never ceasing tears of Penitence.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: O rise! this posture heaps new guilt on me! now you over-pay me.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Have I not used thee like a Villain! For almost ten long years depriv'd thee of my Love, and ruin'd all thy Fortune! But I will labour, dig, beg or starve, to give new proofs of my unfeign'd Affection.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Forbear this tenderness, least I repent of having mov'd your Soul so far: you shall not need to beg. Heav'n has provided for us beyond its common care. 'Tis now near two years since my Uncle Sir William Wealthy sent you the news of my pretended death, knowing the Extravagance of your Temper he thought it fit you shou'd believe no other of me; and about a month after he had sent you that advice, poor man, he dyed, and left me in the full possession of two thousand pounds a year, which I now cannot offer as a Gift, because my Duty, and your lawfull Right, makes you the undisputed Master of it.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: How have I labour'd for my own Undoing, while in despite of all my Follies, kind Heav'n resolv'd my Happiness.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Madam, Sir William Wisewoud has sent your Ladiship the Writings you desired him, and says he'll wait upon you immediately.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Now Sir, if you please to withdraw awhile, you may inform your self how fair a Fortune you are Master of.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: None, none that can outweigh a Virtuous Mind, while in my Arms I thus can circle thee, I grasp more Treasure, than in a Day the posting Sun can travail o're. Oh! why have I so long been blind to the Perfections of thy Mind and Person! Not knowing thee a Wife, I found thee Charming beyond the wishes of Luxurious Love. Is it then a Name, a Word, shall rob thee of thy Worth? Can Fancy be a surer Guide to Happiness than Reason? Oh! I have wander'd like a benighted wretch, and lost my self in Lifes Unpleasing Journey.
sp.l: 'Twas heedless Fancy first, that made me stray,
But Reason now breaks forth, and lights me on my way.

div.head: The Scene changes to an Entry. Enter 3 or 4 Servants.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.p: Prithee Tom make hast below there; my Lady has order'd Dinner at half an hour after one precisely: look out some of the Red that came in last.

div.stage: Two of the Servants hawl Snap and Amanda's Woman out of the Cellar.

sp.speaker: 2 Serv.
sp.p: Come Sir, come out here, and show your face. Wom. Oh I am undone; ruin'd!

sp.speaker: 2 Serv.
sp.p: Pray Sir, who are you, and what was your Business, and how in the Devil's Name came you in Here?

sp.speaker: Snap.
3 Serv.
sp.p: Pray Mrs. Anne how came you two together in the Cellar?

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Why he—he—pu—pu—pull'd me in.

sp.speaker: 3 Serv.
sp.p: But how the Devil came he in?

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: He fe—fe—fe—fel in.

sp.speaker: 2 Serv.
sp.p: How came he into the House?

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: I don—do—don't know.

sp.speaker: 2 Serv.
sp.p: Ah! you are a Crocodile; I thought what was the reason I cou'd never get a good word from you! What, in a Cellar too! But come, Sir, we will take care of you however. Bring him along, we will first carry him before my Lady; and then Toss him in a Blanket.

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.p: Nay but Gentlemen! dear Gentlemen.

div.stage: Enter Loveless, Amanda, E. Wor. Y. Wor. Nar. and Hill.

sp.speaker: E. W.
sp.p: This is indeed a joyfull Day, we must all Congratulate your Happiness.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Which while our lives permit us to enjoy, we must still reflect with Gratitude on the generous Author of it: Sir, we owe you more than words can pay you.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Words are indeed too weak; therefore let my Gratitude be Dumb till it can speak in Actions.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: The success of the Design I thought on, sufficiently rewards me.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: When I reflect upon Amanda's past Afflictions, I cou'd almost weep to think of his unexpected Change of Fortune.

sp.speaker: E. W.
sp.p: Methinks her fair Example shou'd perswade all constant Wives ne'er to Repine at unrewarded Virtue. Nay ev'n my Brother being the first promoter of it, has atton'd for all the looseness of his Character.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I never can return his kindness.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.p: In a short time Sir, I suppose you'll meet with an Opportunity, if you can find a Receipt to preserve Love after his Honey-Moon's over.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: The Receipt is easily found, Madam; Love's a tender Plant, which cann't live out of a warm Bed: you must take care with undissembled Kindness to keep him from the Northern Blast of Jealousie.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.p: But I have heard your Experienced Lovers make use of Coldness, and that's more Agreeable to my Inclination.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Coldness, Madam, before Marriage, like throwing a little Water upon a clear Fire, makes it burn the fiercer: but after Marriage you must still take care to lay on fresh Fuel.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.p: Oh▪ fie, Sir! how many Examples have we of Mens hating their Wives for being too fond of 'em?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: No wonder Madam: you may stifle a Flame by heaping on too great a Load.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.p: Nay Sir, if there be no other way of destroying his Passion; for me he may love till Doomsday.

sp.speaker: E. W.
sp.p: Humph! don't you smell Powder, Gentlemen? Sir Novelty is not far of.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: What not our Fellow Collegian, I hope, that was expell'd the University for Beating the Proctor.

sp.speaker: E. W.
sp.p: The same.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Does that Weed grow still?

sp.speaker: E. W.
sp.p: Ay faith, and as rank as ever, as you shall see, for here he comes.

sp.speaker: Sir No.
sp.p: Ladies your humble Servant; Dear Loveless let me Embrace thee, I am o'er-joy'd at thy good Fortune: stop my Vitals—the whole Town rings of it already—my Lady Tattletongue has tired a Pair of Horses in spreading the News about. Hearing Gentlemen that you were all met upon an Extraordinary good Occasion, I cou'd not resist this opportunity of joyning my Joy with yours: for you must know I am—

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.p: Married, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir No.
sp.p: To my Liberty, Madam, I am just parted from my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.p: And pray Sir, how do you find your self after it?

sp.speaker: Sir No.
sp.p: Th ehappiest Man alive, Madam, Pleasant! Easie! Gay! Light! and Free as Air: hah; (Capers) I beg your Ladyship's Pardon, Madam, but upon my Soul I cannot confine my Rapture.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.p: Are you so indifferent Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir No.
sp.p: Oh! Madam she's engaged already to a Temple Beau! I saw 'em in a Coach together so fond! and bore it with as unmov'd a Countenance as Tom Worthy does a thundering Jest in a Comedy when the whole House roars at it.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: Pray Sir, what occasion'd your Seperation?

sp.speaker: Sir No.
sp.p: Why this Sir,—you must know she being still possest with a Brace of Implacable Devils, call'd Revenge and Jealousie, dogg'd me this Morning to the Chocolate-house, where I was oblig'd to leave a Letter for a young foolish Girl, that—(you will excuse me Sir) which I had no sooner delivered to the Maid of the House; but whip! she snatches it out of her hand, flew at her like a Dragon, tore off her Head-Close, flung down three or four Setts of Lemonade-Glasses, Dasht my Lord Whiffles Chocolate in his Face, Cut him over the Nose, And had like to have strangled me in my own Steinkirk.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Pray Sir, how did this end?

sp.speaker: Sir No.
sp.p: Comically, stop my Vitals! for in the Cloud of Powder, that she had batter'd out of the Beaux Periwigs I stole away: After which I sent a Friend to her, with an Offer, which she readily accepted: Three hundred pound a year during life, provided she wou'd renounce all claims to me, and resign my Person to my own disposal.

sp.speaker: E. W.
sp.p: Methinks, Sir Novelty, you were a little too extravagant in your Settlement, considering how the price of Women is fallen.

sp.speaker: Sir No.
sp.p: Therefore I did it—to be the first man shou'd raise their price: For the Devil take me, but the Women of the Town now come down so low, that my very Footman, while he kept my Place t'other day at the Playhouse, carry'd a Mask out of the Side-Box with him, and stop my Vitals, the Rogue is now taking Physick for't.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.p: Come bring him along there.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: How now! hah! Snap in hold: Pray let's know the business; Release him Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.p: Why, an't please you, Sir, this Fellow was taken in the Cellar with my Lady's Woman! she says he kept her in by force, and was rude to her: she stands crying here without, and begs her Ladyship to do her Justice.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Mr. Loveless, we are both the occasion of this Misfortune, and for the poor Girl's Reputation-sake, something shou'd be done.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Snap, answer me directly, have you lain with this poor Girl?

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.p: Why, truly Sir, Imagining you were doing little less with my Lady, I must confess, I did commit Familiarity with her, or so Sir!

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Then you shall marry her, Sir! no reply unless it be your Promise.

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.p: Marry her, O Lord, Sir! after I have lain with her? why, Sir! how the Devil can you think a Man can have any Stomach to his Dinner, after he has had three or four Slices off of the Spit?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Well Sirrah! to renew your Appetite, and because thou hast been my old Acquaintance, I'll give thee an 100 l. with her, and thirty Pound a Year during life, to set you up in some honest Imployment.

sp.speaker: Snap.
sp.p: Ah! Sir, now I understand you, Heav'n reward you! Well Sir, I partly find that the gentile Scenes of our lives are pretty well over; and I thank Heav'n, that I have so much Grace left, that I can repent, when I have no more Opportunities of being wicked,—come Spouse! (She Enters) here's my hand, the rest of my Body shall be forth-coming, ah! little did my Master and I think last night that we were robbing our own Orchards!

sp.speaker: E. W.
sp.p: Brother, stand upon your Guard! here comes Sir William.

sp.speaker: Sir W.
sp.p: Joy, joy to you all! Madam, I Congratulate your good Fortune. Well, my dear Rogue must not I give thee Joy too? ha!

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: If you please, Sir: but I confess, I have more than I deserve already.

sp.speaker: Sir W.
sp.p: And art thou marry'd?

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I am marry'd!

sp.speaker: Sir W.
sp.p: Odso, I am glad on't: I dare swear, thou dost not grudge me the 5000 l.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: Not I really Sir: you have given me all my Soul cou'd wish for, but the Addition of a Fathers Blessing.

sp.speaker: Sir W.
sp.p: Humh! what dost thou mean? I am none of thy Father.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: This Lady is your Daughter, Sir, I hope.

sp.speaker: Sir W.
sp.p: Prithee get up! prithee get up! thou art stark mad! true, I believe she may be my Daughter: well, and so Sir!

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: If she be not, I'm certain she's my Wife, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir. W.
sp.p: Humh! Mr. Worthy, pray Sir do me the favour to help me to understand your Brother a little—do you know any thing of his being married?

sp.speaker: E. W.
sp.p: Then without any abuse, Sir William, he married your Daughter this very Morning, not an hour ago, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir W.
sp.p: Pray Sir whose consent had you, who advis'd you to it?

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: Our mutual Love and your consent Sir, which these Writings, entituling her to a thousand Pound a year, and this Bond, whereby you have oblig'd your self to pay me five thousand Pound upon our day of Marriage, are sufficient proofs of.

sp.speaker: Sir W.
sp.p: He, he! I gave your Brother such a Bond, Sir.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: You did so! but the obligation is to me; look there Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir W.
sp.p: Very good! this is my hand, I must confess Sir: and what then?

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: Why then I expect my five thousand Pound, Sir: pray Sir, do you know my Name?

sp.speaker: Sir W.
sp.p: I am not drunk Sir, I am sure it was Worthy, and Iack, or Tom, or Dick, or something.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: No Sir, I'll show you—'tis William, look you there Sir: you shou'd have taken more care of the Lawyer Sir, that fill'd up the Blank.

sp.speaker: E. W.
sp.p: So now his Eyes are open!

sp.speaker: Sir W.
sp.p: And have you married my Daughter against my Consent, and trickt me out of 5000 l. Sir?

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: His Brother, Sir, has married me too with my Consent, and I am Not trickt out of 5000 l.

sp.speaker: Sir W.
sp.p: Insulting Witch! look ye Sir! I never had a substantial Cause to be angry in my life before: but now I have reason on my side, I will indulge my Indignation most immoderately: I must confess, I have not patience to wait the slow redress of a Tedious Law-Suit! therefore am resolv'd to right my self the nearest way—draw, draw Sir, you must not enjoy my five thousand Pound, tho' I fling as much more after it in procuring a Pardon for killing you. (They hold him.) Let me come at him, I'll murder him! I'll cut him! I'll tear him! I'll Broil him! and eat him! a Rogue! a Dog! a Cursed Dog! a Cut-throat, murdering Dog!

sp.speaker: E. W.
